gameData.title: Red Team Simulation Mission Pack
gameData.description: A multi-mission decision-tree red team simulation pack with realistic, sector-specific authorized exercises.

games.title: Acheron Bank Group: Hybrid Identity Breach Simulation
games.description: Financial Services mission. Objective: obtain controlled access to merger-planning files for Project Chimera. Crown jewel: the M&A SharePoint/Fileshare containing Project Chimera due-diligence documents.

missionBrief.objective: obtain controlled access to merger-planning files for Project Chimera
missionBrief.crownJewel: the M&A SharePoint/Fileshare containing Project Chimera due-diligence documents
missionBrief.environment: Hybrid AD + Entra ID, O365, Windows endpoints, Citrix, Azure storage
missionBrief.constraints: No customer transaction disruption, no payment systems impact, and proof-only exfiltration of staged sample files.
missionBrief.defenses: EDR on endpoints, email filtering, SIEM correlation, privileged access workstations for admins.

questions.text: Authorized engagement kickoff for Acheron Bank Group (Financial Services). Mission objective: obtain controlled access to merger-planning files for Project Chimera. Environment includes Hybrid AD + Entra ID, O365, Windows endpoints, Citrix, Azure storage. External surface in scope: VPN portal, OWA, public investor microsites, vendor SSO portal. Constraints: No customer transaction disruption, no payment systems impact, and proof-only exfiltration of staged sample files. What is your first move?

choices.option: Start with passive recon and attack-path mapping
choices.hint: Lowest-noise option; build context before touching targets.

choices.option: Probe external perimeter carefully for exposed services
choices.hint: Fast signal, medium detection risk if rushed.

choices.option: Prioritize identity-focused access (phishing/SSO path)
choices.hint: High payoff in modern environments, but monitored.

choices.option: Manually enumerate public-facing apps and content leaks
choices.hint: Often reveals forgotten admin paths and data leaks.

questions.text: Passive recon reveals staff roles, vendor relationships, and technology fingerprints. You confirm Fraud monitoring is sensitive to unusual authentication patterns. Which recon lane do you push next?

choices.option: Map high-value identities and admin workflows
Assess trust and access paths through external legal due-diligence portal vendor
Search code/repos/docs for exposed secrets and tokens
Fingerprint public apps, subdomains, and login flows

questions.text: External probing can target VPN, portals, and support systems. Blue team controls include EDR on endpoints, email filtering, SIEM correlation, privileged access workstations for admins. Choose the approach.

choices.option: Low-rate validated probing with focus on misconfiguration
choices.hint: Stealthier than broad scanning; prioritize banners and auth flows.

choices.option: Broad multi-port scan across all exposed ranges
choices.hint: Noisy pattern likely to hit SOC detections.

choices.option: Attempt credential brute-force on exposed auth endpoints
choices.hint: High lockout risk, poor tradecraft.

choices.option: Compare response behavior/WAF rules and enumerate hidden paths
choices.hint: Good intel without immediate exploitation.

questions.text: Identity-first path selected. Acheron Bank Group uses modern auth and conditional access in parts of the environment. What's your play?

choices.option: Noisy MFA push-fatigue style access attempt
choices.hint: Likely to trigger user reports and SOC review.

choices.option: Targeted credential capture / login workflow simulation (authorized exercise)
choices.hint: High-value if pretext quality is good.

choices.option: Constrained password spray against approved test users
choices.hint: Can work if done carefully within RoE.

choices.option: OAuth/app-consent style identity pivot simulation (approved scope)
choices.hint: Modern path; watch audit trails.

questions.text: Manual public enum finds several apps, docs, and vendor endpoints tied to acheronbank.local. Which lead do you chase?

choices.option: Misconfigured portal/admin function leaks internal identifiers
choices.hint: Can produce valid foothold or internal route.

choices.option: Exposed object storage / backup index tied to Azure tenant and storage accounts
choices.hint: Cloud-side misconfig may shortcut internal access.

choices.option: Outdated admin panel — try password guessing
choices.hint: Bad idea: lockouts and telemetry.

choices.option: Public docs and metadata yield usernames, emails, and naming conventions

questions.text: Vendor path analysis shows external legal due-diligence portal vendor has trusted workflows with Acheron Bank Group. How do you test the supply-chain angle in this simulation?

choices.option: Enumerate trust boundaries, file exchange paths, and service accounts
choices.hint: Best signal-to-noise; maps realistic pivot paths.

choices.option: Aggressive social engineering of vendor helpdesk
choices.hint: High legal/process risk and low realism for this exercise.

choices.option: Review exposed vendor documentation and access artifacts
choices.hint: More intel before interacting.

choices.option: Ignore vendor path and return to primary recon

questions.text: Outcome: You find old deployment notes and usernames, but no live secrets. Useful intel on naming, environments, and change windows.

choices.option: Return to recon with better context

questions.text: Outcome: Vendor docs expose workflow details and a likely integration endpoint. You now understand how data moves between organizations.

choices.option: Use this to pivot toward identity/cloud paths

questions.text: Outcome: WAF and app behavior analysis reveals hidden routes and error patterns, but no direct exploit path. You gain target prioritization.

choices.option: Follow up with manual app enumeration

questions.text: Outcome: Public content yields valid usernames, business units, and likely admin naming patterns. Identity attacks become more credible.

choices.option: Move into identity-focused access path

questions.text: Outcome: Vendor helpdesk reports the pretext attempt. The exercise is flagged as unrealistic/noisy. Engagement controller pauses the path.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Outcome: Broad scanning triggers IDS/SIEM alerts and rate limiting. SOC opens an investigation and your external source is burned.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Outcome: Authentication lockouts and anomaly detections fire. This path is considered too noisy for the mission goals.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Outcome: Users report suspicious prompts. Detection and response time collapses your window. Identity path is shut down.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Initial foothold achieved on a low-priv endpoint/account in user workstation VLAN, file server, Citrix jump hosts, identity sync server. What do you do next?

choices.option: Enumerate local host, sessions, and enterprise apps quietly
choices.hint: Good first step: collect context before moving.

choices.option: Prioritize identity/session token discovery and delegated access
choices.hint: Modern path; often beats noisy local privesc.

choices.option: Scan internal subnets aggressively to find targets
choices.hint: Likely to trip segmentation and EDR detections.

choices.option: Pull app configs / logs for references to Azure tenant and storage accounts
choices.hint: May reveal cloud or integration pivots.

questions.text: Cloud/identity-adjacent access path opened. You have visibility into integrations involving Azure tenant and storage accounts. What is the best next action?

choices.option: Enumerate role assignments, app registrations, and storage access scope
choices.hint: Maps real privilege paths without immediate abuse.

choices.option: Reuse a valid token/session to access an approved management interface
choices.hint: Can accelerate pathing if done within scope.

choices.option: Make configuration changes immediately to force persistence
choices.hint: Changes are noisy and quickly audited.

choices.option: Collect metadata and return to host-based exploration

questions.text: Outcome: Cloud metadata confirms where privileged workflows and data syncs occur. You now have a cleaner target list.

choices.option: Continue from the foothold with improved targeting

questions.text: Outcome: Internal scanning patterns trigger NDR/EDR alerts and network controls. Your foothold is contained.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Outcome: Unauthorized config changes are detected and rolled back. Audit logs make attribution trivial in the exercise timeline.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Privilege escalation / credential access phase. Goal is a safe path toward the M&A SharePoint/Fileshare containing Project Chimera due-diligence documents without destabilizing systems. Choose a route.

choices.option: Exploit a local misconfiguration or service weakness (simulated)
choices.hint: Fast if present; stay within proof-only bounds.

choices.option: Abuse delegated permissions / service account scope
choices.hint: Often realistic in hybrid environments.

choices.option: Run noisy credential dumping immediately
choices.hint: EDR usually sees this; poor stealth.

choices.option: Collect credentials/tickets for offline validation and selective reuse
choices.hint: Slower, better OPSEC.

questions.text: Identity-centric escalation path. You see app roles, group memberships, and admin workflows across Hybrid AD + Entra ID, O365, Windows endpoints, Citrix, Azure storage. What's next?

choices.option: Map admin sign-in patterns and privileged workstations/jump hosts
choices.hint: Supports low-noise lateral movement.

choices.option: Abuse over-privileged app/service principal access (simulated)
choices.hint: Can establish durable access; watch audit logs.

choices.option: Attempt mass token replay across many services
choices.hint: High anomaly score; likely blocked.

choices.option: Harvest only what you need and keep access ephemeral

questions.text: Outcome: You avoid persistence and keep the footprint small. Stealth bonus earned; path remains viable with limited dwell time.

choices.option: Proceed to lateral movement and target selection

questions.text: Outcome: EDR blocks the tooling and isolates the endpoint. The SOC catches the escalation attempt.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Outcome: Identity risk controls flag unusual token reuse across services. Conditional access and SOC response shut the path down.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Persistence/privileged access management decision point. Blue team auditing is active. How do you maintain operational access (if at all)?

choices.option: Create a loud backdoor account or permanent admin change
choices.hint: Quick but unrealistic for stealth; heavily audited.

choices.option: Low-noise scheduled/WMI/service persistence (simulated) on a non-critical system
choices.hint: Viable but still risky if overused.

choices.option: Identity/cloud persistence via approved simulation of app registration or delegated access
choices.hint: Modern path with audit visibility.

choices.option: Skip persistence and continue with time-boxed access
choices.hint: Stealthier; may reduce retry options later.

questions.text: Outcome: You intentionally remain ephemeral. This improves stealth but leaves no safety net if the foothold burns.

choices.option: Continue to lateral movement

questions.text: Outcome: Privileged change monitoring catches the persistence move. IR response begins and your dwell time ends.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Lateral movement / pathing. From your foothold you can see parts of user workstation VLAN, file server, Citrix jump hosts, identity sync server. Which path best aligns with mission constraints?

choices.option: Move toward business data/file services tied to the mission objective
choices.hint: Direct route if access is sufficient.

choices.option: Target admin workstation or jump host used by privileged staff
choices.hint: High value, but be selective.

choices.option: Attempt direct access to the crown-jewel system immediately
choices.hint: Segmentation, PAM, or EDR likely catches this jump.

choices.option: Map identity/ACL relationships first, then choose the path
choices.hint: Slower but often wins.

questions.text: Outcome: Direct jump to the M&A SharePoint/Fileshare containing Project Chimera due-diligence documents is blocked/flagged by segmentation or monitored admin controls.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Collection/staging phase. You have a path toward staged M&A diligence documents. How do you prove impact safely?

choices.option: Collect only scoped sample records/files and preserve timestamps
choices.hint: Best practice for proof-only exercises.

choices.option: Bulk copy broad datasets for convenience
choices.hint: High volume triggers alerts and violates minimization.

choices.option: Use an approved business-like transfer/staging path in the environment (simulated)
choices.hint: Blends better and demonstrates realism.

choices.option: Modify data to prove write access
choices.hint: Shows impact, but often outside preferred proof path.

questions.text: Outcome: Bulk data movement triggers DLP/volume alerts and fails mission minimization requirements.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Outcome: Write-access proof is demonstrated, but the path is marked as higher risk than required. Debrief credit is partial.

choices.option: Proceed to exfil/report decision

questions.text: Objective reached: you can access staged M&A diligence documents. Final step—how do you conclude the exercise?

choices.option: Exfiltrate a staged sample via approved covert simulation path
choices.hint: Demonstrates end-to-end impact with controlled data.

choices.option: Exfiltrate via normal application/business channel emulation
choices.hint: Often more realistic and less noisy than 'movie hacker' channels.

choices.option: Stop at proof of access and report without exfiltration
choices.hint: Strong ethical choice; may be partial depending on objectives.

choices.option: Keep exploring beyond objective to find more systems
choices.hint: Scope creep gets you in trouble faster than defenders.

questions.text: Outcome: Success. You demonstrated a full attack path and controlled exfiltration of staged data from Acheron Bank Group without violating mission constraints.
Outcome: Success. You completed the mission by using a business-like transfer path to demonstrate realistic data access/exfiltration risk.

Outcome: Partial success. You proved access to the M&A SharePoint/Fileshare containing Project Chimera due-diligence documents and documented the path, but stopped before exfiltration per operator judgment.
Outcome: Scope creep increases dwell time and telemetry. The exercise controller marks the mission as failed due to overreach.

choices.option: Restart mission

games.title: St. Isidore Health: Clinical IT Red Team Simulation
games.description: Healthcare mission. Objective: reach the radiology scheduling environment and access staged patient workflow exports. Crown jewel: the radiology scheduling and imaging workflow server (staged dataset only).

games.title: IronVale Manufacturing: OT/IT Segmentation Simulation
games.description: Manufacturing mission. Objective: demonstrate a path from corporate IT to the plant historian network without touching controllers. Crown jewel: the OT historian server containing staged production metrics.

questions.text: External probing can target VPN, portals, and support systems. Blue team controls include EDR, SIEM, segmented admin access, strict monitoring on engineering jump hosts. Choose the approach.

choices.option: Low-rate validated probing with focus on misconfiguration
choices.hint: Stealthier than broad scanning; prioritize banners and auth flows.

choices.option: Broad multi-port scan across all exposed ranges
choices.hint: Noisy pattern likely to hit SOC detections.

choices.option: Attempt credential brute-force on exposed auth endpoints
choices.hint: High lockout risk, poor tradecraft.

choices.option: Compare response behavior/WAF rules and enumerate hidden paths
choices.hint: Good intel without immediate exploitation.

questions.text: Identity-first path selected. BlueRiver Energy uses modern auth and conditional access in parts of the environment. What's your play?

choices.option: Noisy MFA push-fatigue style access attempt
choices.hint: Likely to trigger user reports and SOC review.

choices.option: Targeted credential capture / login workflow simulation (authorized exercise)
choices.hint: High-value if pretext quality is good.

choices.option: Constrained password spray against approved test users
choices.hint: Can work if done carefully within RoE.

choices.option: OAuth/app-consent style identity pivot simulation (approved scope)
choices.hint: Modern path; watch audit trails.

questions.text: Manual public enum finds several apps, docs, and vendor endpoints tied to blueriver.local. Which lead do you chase?

choices.option: Misconfigured portal/admin function leaks internal identifiers
choices.hint: Can produce valid foothold or internal route.

choices.option: Exposed object storage / backup index tied to M365 and cloud file sync services
choices.hint: Cloud-side misconfig may shortcut internal access.

choices.option: Outdated admin panel — try password guessing
choices.hint: Bad idea: lockouts and telemetry.

choices.option: Public docs and metadata yield usernames, emails, and naming conventions

questions.text: Vendor path analysis shows maintenance scheduling software provider has trusted workflows with BlueRiver Energy. How do you test the supply-chain angle in this simulation?

choices.option: Enumerate trust boundaries, file exchange paths, and service accounts
choices.hint: Best signal-to-noise; maps realistic pivot paths.

choices.option: Aggressive social engineering of vendor helpdesk
choices.hint: High legal/process risk and low realism for this exercise.

choices.option: Review exposed vendor documentation and access artifacts
choices.hint: More intel before interacting.

choices.option: Ignore vendor path and return to primary recon

questions.text: Outcome: You find old deployment notes and usernames, but no live secrets. Useful intel on naming, environments, and change windows.

choices.option: Return to recon with better context

questions.text: Outcome: Vendor docs expose workflow details and a likely integration endpoint. You now understand how data moves between organizations.

choices.option: Use this to pivot toward identity/cloud paths

questions.text: Outcome: WAF and app behavior analysis reveals hidden routes and error patterns, but no direct exploit path. You gain target prioritization.

choices.option: Follow up with manual app enumeration

questions.text: Outcome: Public content yields valid usernames, business units, and likely admin naming patterns. Identity attacks become more credible.

choices.option: Move into identity-focused access path

questions.text: Outcome: Vendor helpdesk reports the pretext attempt. The exercise is flagged as unrealistic/noisy. Engagement controller pauses the path.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Outcome: Broad scanning triggers IDS/SIEM alerts and rate limiting. SOC opens an investigation and your external source is burned.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Outcome: Authentication lockouts and anomaly detections fire. This path is considered too noisy for the mission goals.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Outcome: Users report suspicious prompts. Detection and response time collapses your window. Identity path is shut down.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Initial foothold achieved on a low-priv endpoint/account in corp endpoints, planning file server, engineering jump host, identity systems. What do you do next?

choices.option: Enumerate local host, sessions, and enterprise apps quietly
choices.hint: Good first step: collect context before moving.

choices.option: Prioritize identity/session token discovery and delegated access
choices.hint: Modern path; often beats noisy local privesc.

choices.option: Scan internal subnets aggressively to find targets
choices.hint: Likely to trip segmentation and EDR detections.

choices.option: Pull app configs / logs for references to M365 and cloud file sync services
choices.hint: May reveal cloud or integration pivots.

questions.text: Cloud/identity-adjacent access path opened. You have visibility into integrations involving M365 and cloud file sync services. What is the best next action?

choices.option: Enumerate role assignments, app registrations, and storage access scope
choices.hint: Maps real privilege paths without immediate abuse.

choices.option: Reuse a valid token/session to access an approved management interface
choices.hint: Can accelerate pathing if done within scope.

choices.option: Make configuration changes immediately to force persistence
choices.hint: Changes are noisy and quickly audited.

choices.option: Collect metadata and return to host-based exploration

questions.text: Outcome: Cloud metadata confirms where privileged workflows and data syncs occur. You now have a cleaner target list.

choices.option: Continue from the foothold with improved targeting

questions.text: Outcome: Internal scanning patterns trigger NDR/EDR alerts and network controls. Your foothold is contained.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Outcome: Unauthorized config changes are detected and rolled back. Audit logs make attribution trivial in the exercise timeline.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Privilege escalation / credential access phase. Goal is a safe path toward the outage planning and maintenance scheduling share (staged planning docs) without destabilizing systems. Choose a route.

choices.option: Exploit a local misconfiguration or service weakness (simulated)
choices.hint: Fast if present; stay within proof-only bounds.

choices.option: Abuse delegated permissions / service account scope
choices.hint: Often realistic in hybrid environments.

choices.option: Run noisy credential dumping immediately
choices.hint: EDR usually sees this; poor stealth.

choices.option: Collect credentials/tickets for offline validation and selective reuse
choices.hint: Slower, better OPSEC.

questions.text: Identity-centric escalation path. You see app roles, group memberships, and admin workflows across AD, VPN, M365, engineering jump hosts, Linux servers, segmented operations network. What's next?

choices.option: Map admin sign-in patterns and privileged workstations/jump hosts
choices.hint: Supports low-noise lateral movement.

choices.option: Abuse over-privileged app/service principal access (simulated)
choices.hint: Can establish durable access; watch audit logs.

choices.option: Attempt mass token replay across many services
choices.hint: High anomaly score; likely blocked.

choices.option: Harvest only what you need and keep access ephemeral

questions.text: Outcome: You avoid persistence and keep the footprint small. Stealth bonus earned; path remains viable with limited dwell time.

choices.option: Proceed to lateral movement and target selection

questions.text: Outcome: EDR blocks the tooling and isolates the endpoint. The SOC catches the escalation attempt.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Outcome: Identity risk controls flag unusual token reuse across services. Conditional access and SOC response shut the path down.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Persistence/privileged access management decision point. Blue team auditing is active. How do you maintain operational access (if at all)?

choices.option: Create a loud backdoor account or permanent admin change
choices.hint: Quick but unrealistic for stealth; heavily audited.

choices.option: Low-noise scheduled/WMI/service persistence (simulated) on a non-critical system
choices.hint: Viable but still risky if overused.

choices.option: Identity/cloud persistence via approved simulation of app registration or delegated access
choices.hint: Modern path with audit visibility.

choices.option: Skip persistence and continue with time-boxed access
choices.hint: Stealthier; may reduce retry options later.

questions.text: Outcome: You intentionally remain ephemeral. This improves stealth but leaves no safety net if the foothold burns.

choices.option: Continue to lateral movement

questions.text: Outcome: Privileged change monitoring catches the persistence move. IR response begins and your dwell time ends.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Lateral movement / pathing. From your foothold you can see parts of corp endpoints, planning file server, engineering jump host, identity systems. Which path best aligns with mission constraints?

choices.option: Move toward business data/file services tied to the mission objective
choices.hint: Direct route if access is sufficient.

choices.option: Target admin workstation or jump host used by privileged staff
choices.hint: High value, but be selective.

choices.option: Attempt direct access to the crown-jewel system immediately
choices.hint: Segmentation, PAM, or EDR likely catches this jump.

choices.option: Map identity/ACL relationships first, then choose the path
choices.hint: Slower but often wins.

questions.text: Outcome: Direct jump to the outage planning and maintenance scheduling share (staged planning docs) is blocked/flagged by segmentation or monitored admin controls.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Collection/staging phase. You have a path toward staged outage planning documents. How do you prove impact safely?

choices.option: Collect only scoped sample records/files and preserve timestamps
choices.hint: Best practice for proof-only exercises.

choices.option: Bulk copy broad datasets for convenience
choices.hint: High volume triggers alerts and violates minimization.

choices.option: Use an approved business-like transfer/staging path in the environment (simulated)
choices.hint: Blends better and demonstrates realism.

choices.option: Modify data to prove write access
choices.hint: Shows impact, but often outside preferred proof path.

questions.text: Outcome: Bulk data movement triggers DLP/volume alerts and fails mission minimization requirements.

choices.option: Restart mission

questions.text: Outcome: Write-access proof is demonstrated, but the path is marked as higher risk than required. Debrief credit is partial.

choices.option: Proceed to exfil/report decision

questions.text: Objective reached: you can access staged outage planning documents. Final step—how do you conclude the exercise?

choices.option: Exfiltrate a staged sample via approved covert simulation path
choices.hint: Demonstrates end-to-end impact with controlled data.

choices.option: Exfiltrate via normal application/business channel emulation
choices.hint: Often more realistic and less noisy than 'movie hacker' channels.

choices.option: Stop at proof of access and report without exfiltration
choices.hint: Strong ethical choice; may be partial depending on objectives.

choices.option: Keep exploring beyond objective to find more systems
choices.hint: Scope creep gets you in trouble faster than defenders.

questions.text: Outcome: Success. You demonstrated a full attack path and controlled exfiltration of staged data from BlueRiver Energy without violating mission constraints.
Outcome: Success. You completed the mission by using a business-like transfer path to demonstrate realistic data access/exfiltration risk.

Outcome: Partial success. You proved access to the outage planning and maintenance scheduling share (staged planning docs) and documented the path, but stopped before exfiltration per operator judgment.
Outcome: Scope creep increases dwell time and telemetry. The exercise controller marks the mission as failed due to overreach.

choices.option: Restart mission
